abstract_sentences.1: We present the first parser for UCCA, a cross-linguistically applicable framework for semantic representation, which builds on extensive typological work and supports rapid annotation.
abstract_sentences.2: UCCA poses a challenge for existing parsing techniques, as it exhibits reentrancy (resulting in DAG structures), discontinuous structures and non-terminal nodes corresponding to complex semantic units.
abstract_sentences.3: To our knowledge, the conjunction of these formal properties is not supported by any existing parser.
abstract_sentences.4: Our transition-based parser, which uses a novel transition set and features based on bidirectional LSTMs, has value not just for UCCA parsing: its ability to handle more general graph structures can inform the development of parsers for other semantic DAG structures, and in languages that frequently use discontinuous structures.

https://doi.org/10.18653/v1/P17-1104  1 Introduction  Universal Conceptual Cognitive Annotation (UCCA, Abend and Rappoport, 2013) is a crosslinguistically applicable semantic representation scheme, building on the established Basic Linguistic Theory typological framework (Dixon, 2010a,b, 2012), and Cognitive Linguistics literature (Croft and Cruse, 2004).
body_sentences.2: It has demonstrated applicability to multiple languages, including English, French, German and Czech, support for rapid annotation by non-experts (assisted by an accessible annotation interface (Abend et al., 2017)), and stability under translation (Sulem et al., 2015).
body_sentences.3: It has also proven useful for machine translation evaluation (Birch et al., 2016).
body_sentences.4: UCCA differs from syntactic schemes in terms of content and formal structure.
body_sentences.5:
It exhibits reentrancy,
discontinuous nodes and non-terminals, which no single existing parser supports.
body_sentences.6: Lacking a parser, UCCA’s applicability has been so far limited, a gap this work addresses.
body_sentences.7: We present the first UCCA parser, TUPA (Transition-based UCCA Parser), building on recent advances in discontinuous constituency and dependency graph parsing, and further introducing novel transitions and features for UCCA.
body_sentences.8: Transition-based techniques are a natural starting point for UCCA parsing, given the conceptual similarity of UCCA’s distinctions, centered around predicate-argument structures, to distinctions expressed by dependency schemes, and the achievements of transition-based methods in dependency parsing (Dyer et al., 2015; Andor et al., 2016; Kiperwasser and Goldberg, 2016).
body_sentences.9: We are further motivated by the strength of transition-based methods in related tasks, including dependency graph parsing (Sagae and Tsujii, 2008; Ribeyre et al., 2014; Tokgöz and Eryiğit, 2015), constituency parsing (Sagae and Lavie, 2005; Zhang and Clark, 2009; Zhu et al., 2013; Maier, 2015; Maier and Lichte, 2016), AMR parsing (Wang et al., 2015a,b, 2016; Misra and Artzi, 2016; Goodman et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2016; Damonte et al., 2017) and CCG parsing (Zhang and Clark, 2011; Ambati et al., 2015, 2016).
body_sentences.10: We evaluate TUPA on the English UCCA corpora, including in-domain and out-of-domain settings.
body_sentences.11: To assess the ability of existing parsers to tackle the task, we develop a conversion procedure from UCCA to bilexical graphs and trees.
body_sentences.12:
Results show superior performance for TUPA, demonstrating the effectiveness of the presented approach.1
The rest of the paper is structured as follows:

body_sentences.18: 2 The UCCA Scheme  UCCA graphs are labeled, directed acyclic graphs (DAGs), whose leaves correspond to the tokens of the text.
body_sentences.19: A node (or unit) corresponds to a terminal or to several terminals (not necessarily contiguous) viewed as a single entity according to semantic or cognitive considerations.
body_sentences.20: Edges bear a category, indicating the role of the sub-unit in the parent relation.
body_sentences.22: UCCA is a multi-layered representation, where each layer corresponds to a “module” of semantic distinctions.
body_sentences.23: UCCA’s foundational layer, targeted in this paper, covers the predicate-argument structure evoked by predicates of all grammatical categories (verbal, nominal, adjectival and others), the inter-relations between them, and other major linguistic phenomena such as coordination and multi-word expressions.
body_sentences.24: The layer’s basic notion is the scene, describing a state, action, movement or some other relation that evolves in time.
body_sentences.25: Each scene contains one main relation (marked as either a Process or a State), as well as one or more Participants.
body_sentences.26: For example, the sentence “After graduation, John moved to Paris” (Figure 1a) contains two scenes, whose main relations are “graduation” and “moved”.
body_sentences.27: “John” is a Participant in both scenes, while “Paris” only in the latter.
body_sentences.28: Further categories account for inter-scene relations and the internal structure of complex arguments and relations (e.g.
body_sentences.30: One incoming edge for each non-root node is marked as primary, and the rest (mostly used for implicit relations and arguments) as remote edges, a distinction made by the annotator.
body_sentences.31: The primary edges thus form a tree structure, whereas the remote edges enable reentrancy, forming a DAG.
body_sentences.32: While parsing technology in general, and transition-based parsing in particular, is wellestablished for syntactic parsing, UCCA has several distinct properties that distinguish it from syntactic representations, mostly UCCA’s tendency to abstract away from syntactic detail that do not affect argument structure.

body_sentences.40: First, non-verbal predicates in UCCA are represented like verbal ones, such as when they appear in copula clauses or noun phrases.
body_sentences.41: Indeed, in Figure 1a, “graduation” and “moved” are considered separate events, despite appearing in the same clause.

body_sentences.44: While in UCCA “trip” evokes a scene in which “John and Mary” is a Participant, a syntactic scheme would analyze this phrase similarly to “John and Mary’s shoes”.
body_sentences.45: These examples demonstrate that a UCCA parser, and more generally semantic parsers, face an additional level of ambiguity compared to their syntactic counterparts (e.g., “after graduation” is formally very similar to “after 2pm”, which does not evoke a scene).
body_sentences.46: Section 6 discusses UCCA in the context of other semantic schemes, such as AMR (Banarescu et al., 2013).
body_sentences.47: Alongside recent progress in dependency parsing into projective trees, there is increasing interest in parsing into representations with more general structural properties (see Section 6).
body_sentences.48: One such property is reentrancy, namely the sharing of semantic units between predicates.
body_sentences.49:
For instance, in Figure 1a, “John” is an argument of both “gradu-
ation” and “moved”, yielding a DAG rather than a tree.
body_sentences.50: A second property is discontinuity, as in Figure 1b, where “gave up” forms a discontinuous semantic unit.
body_sentences.51: Discontinuities are pervasive, e.g., with multi-word expressions (Schneider et al., 2014).
body_sentences.52: Finally, unlike most dependency schemes, UCCA uses non-terminal nodes to represent units comprising more than one word.
body_sentences.53: The use of non-terminal nodes is motivated by constructions with no clear head, including coordination structures (e.g., “John and Mary” in Figure 1c), some multi-word expressions (e.g., “The Haves and the Have Nots”), and prepositional phrases (either the preposition or the head noun can serve as the constituent’s head).
body_sentences.54: To our knowledge, no existing parser supports all structural properties required for UCCA parsing.
body_sentences.55: 3 Transition-based UCCA Parsing  We now turn to presenting TUPA.
body_sentences.56: Building on previous work on parsing reentrancies, discontinuities and non-terminal nodes, we define an extended set of transitions and features that supports the conjunction of these properties.
body_sentences.57: Transition-based parsers (Nivre, 2003) scan the text from start to end, and create the parse incrementally by applying a transition at each step to the parser’s state, defined using three data structures: a buffer B of tokens and nodes to be processed, a stack S of nodes currently being processed, and a graph G = (V,E, `) of constructed nodes and edges, where V is the set of nodes, E is the set of edges, and ` : E → L is the label function, L being the set of possible labels.
body_sentences.58: Some states are marked as terminal, meaning that G is the final output.
body_sentences.59: A classifier is used at each step to select the next transition based on features encoding the parser’s current state.
body_sentences.60: During training, an oracle creates training instances for the classifier, based on gold-standard annotations.
body_sentences.62: Given a sequence of tokens w1, .
body_sentences.65: , wn, we predict a UCCA graph G over the sequence.
body_sentences.66: Parsing starts with a single node on the stack (an artificial root node), and the input tokens in the buffer.
body_sentences.68: In addition to the standard SHIFT and REDUCE operations, we follow previous work in transition-based constituency parsing (Sagae and Lavie, 2005), adding the NODE transition for creating new non-terminal nodes.
body_sentences.69:
For every X ∈ L, NODEX creates a new node on the buffer as a par-
ent of the first element on the stack, with an Xlabeled edge.
body_sentences.70: LEFT-EDGEX and RIGHT-EDGEX create a new primary X-labeled edge between the first two elements on the stack, where the parent is the left or the right node, respectively.
body_sentences.71: As a UCCA node may only have one incoming primary edge, EDGE transitions are disallowed if the child node already has an incoming primary edge.
body_sentences.72: LEFTREMOTEX and RIGHT-REMOTEX do not have this restriction, and the created edge is additionally marked as remote.
body_sentences.73: We distinguish between these two pairs of transitions to allow the parser to create remote edges without the possibility of producing invalid graphs.
body_sentences.74: To support the prediction of multiple parents, node and edge transitions leave the stack unchanged, as in other work on transition-based dependency graph parsing (Sagae and Tsujii, 2008; Ribeyre et al., 2014; Tokgöz and Eryiğit, 2015).
body_sentences.75: REDUCE pops the stack, to allow removing a node once all its edges have been created.
body_sentences.76: To handle discontinuous nodes, SWAP pops the second node on the stack and adds it to the top of the buffer, as with the similarly named transition in previous work (Nivre, 2009; Maier, 2015).
body_sentences.77: Finally, FINISH pops the root node and marks the state as terminal.
body_sentences.79: The choice of classifier and feature representation has been shown to play an important role in transition-based parsing (Chen and Manning, 2014; Andor et al., 2016; Kiperwasser and Goldberg, 2016).
body_sentences.80: To investigate the impact of the type of transition classifier in UCCA parsing, we experiment with three different models.

Starting with a simple and common choice (e.g., Maier and Lichte, 2016), TUPASparse uses a linear classifier with sparse features, trained with the averaged structured perceptron algorithm (Collins and Roark, 2004) and MINUPDATE (Goldberg and Elhadad, 2011): each feature requires a minimum number of updates in training to be included in the model.2

body_sentences.88: Finally, TUPABiLSTM uses a bidirectional LSTM for feature representation, on top of the dense embedding features, an architecture similar to Kiperwasser and Goldberg (2016).
body_sentences.89: The BiLSTM runs on the input tokens in forward and backward directions, yielding a vector representation that is then concatenated with dense features representing the parser state (e.g., existing edge labels and previous parser actions; see below).
body_sentences.90: This representation is then fed into a feedforward network similar to TUPAMLP.
body_sentences.91: The feedforward layers, BiLSTM and embeddings are all trained jointly.
body_sentences.92: For all classifiers, inference is performed greedily, i.e., without beam search.

body_sentences.95: TUPASparse uses binary indicator features representing the words, POS tags, syntactic dependency labels and existing edge labels related to the top four stack elements and the next three buffer elements, in addition to their children and grandchildren in the graph.
body_sentences.96: We also use bi- and trigram features based on these values (Zhang and Clark, 2009; Zhu et al., 2013), features related to discontinuous nodes (Maier, 2015, including separating punctuation and gap type), features representing existing edges and the number of parents and children, as well as the past actions taken by the parser.

body_sentences.100: We additionally use external word embeddings initialized with pre-trained word2vec vectors (Mikolov et al., 2013),4 updated during training.
body_sentences.101: In addition to dropout between NN layers, we apply word dropout (Kiperwasser and Goldberg, 2016): with a certain probability, the embedding for a word is replaced with a zero vector.
body_sentences.102: We do not apply word dropout to the external word embeddings.
body_sentences.103: Finally, for all classifiers we add a novel realvalued feature to the input vector, ratio, corresponding to the ratio between the number of terminals to number of nodes in the graph G. This feature serves as a regularizer for the creation of new nodes, and should be beneficial for other transition-based constituency parsers too.
body_sentences.105: For training the transition classifiers, we use a dynamic oracle (Goldberg and Nivre, 2012), i.e., an oracle that outputs a set of optimal transitions: when applied to the current parser state, the gold standard graph is reachable from the resulting state.
body_sentences.106: For example, the oracle would predict a NODE transition if the stack has on its top a parent in the gold graph that has not been created, but would predict a RIGHT-EDGE transition if the second stack element is a parent of the first element according to the gold graph and the edge between them has not been created.
body_sentences.107: The transition predicted by the classifier is deemed correct and is applied to the parser state to reach the subsequent state, if the transition is included in the set of optimal transitions.

body_sentences.131: As no direct comparison with existing parsers is possible, we compare TUPA to bilexical dependency graph parsers, which support reentrancy and discontinuity but not non-terminal nodes.
body_sentences.132: To facilitate the comparison, we convert our training set into bilexical graphs (see examples in Figure 4), train each of the parsers, and evaluate them by applying them to the test set and then reconstructing UCCA graphs, which are compared with the gold standard.
body_sentences.133: The conversion to bilexical graphs is done by heuristically selecting a head terminal for each non-terminal node, and attaching all terminal descendents to the head terminal.

body_sentences.158: 6 Related Work  While earlier work on anchored12 semantic parsing has mostly concentrated on shallow semantic analysis, focusing on semantic role labeling of verbal argument structures, the focus has recently shifted to parsing of more elaborate representations that account for a wider range of phenomena (Abend and Rappoport, 2017).
body_sentences.160:
Linguistically expressive grammars such as HPSG (Pollard and Sag, 1994), CCG (Steedman, 2000) and TAG (Joshi and Schabes, 1997) provide a theory of the syntax-semantics interface, and have been used as a basis for semantic parsers by defining com-
11We also experimented with a simpler version of TUPA lacking REMOTE transitions, obtaining an increase of up to 2 labeled F-score points on primary edges, at the cost of not being able to predict remote edges.
body_sentences.161: 12By anchored we mean that the semantic representation directly corresponds to the words and phrases of the text.
body_sentences.162: positional semantics on top of them (Flickinger, 2000; Bos, 2005, among others).
body_sentences.163: Depending on the grammar and the implementation, such semantic parsers can support some or all of the structural properties UCCA exhibits.
body_sentences.164: Nevertheless, this line of work differs from our approach in two important ways.
body_sentences.166: UCCA does not attempt to model the syntaxsemantics interface and is thus less coupled with syntax.
body_sentences.167: Second, while grammar-based parsers explicitly model syntax, our approach directly models the relation between tokens and semantic structures, without explicit composition rules.
body_sentences.169: Most closely related to this work is Broad-Coverage Semantic Dependency Parsing (SDP), addressed in two SemEval tasks (Oepen et al., 2014, 2015).
body_sentences.170: Like UCCA parsing, SDP addresses a wide range of semantic phenomena, and supports discontinuous units and reentrancy.
body_sentences.171: In SDP, however, bilexical dependencies are used, and a head must be selected for every relation—even in constructions that have no clear head, such as coordination (Ivanova et al., 2012).
body_sentences.172: The use of non-terminal nodes is a simple way to avoid this liability.
body_sentences.173: SDP also differs from UCCA in the type of distinctions it makes, which are more tightly coupled with syntactic considerations, where UCCA aims to capture purely semantic cross-linguistically applicable notions.
body_sentences.174: For instance, the “poss” label in the DM target representation is used to annotate syntactic possessive constructions, regardless of whether they correspond to semantic ownership (e.g., “John’s dog”) or other semantic relations, such as marking an argument of a nominal predicate (e.g., “John’s kick”).
body_sentences.175: UCCA reflects the difference between these constructions.
body_sentences.176: Recent interest in SDP has yielded numerous works on graph parsing (Ribeyre et al., 2014; Thomson et al., 2014; Almeida and Martins, 2015; Du et al., 2015), including tree approximation (Agić and Koller, 2014; Schluter et al., 2014) and joint syntactic/semantic parsing (Henderson et al., 2013; Swayamdipta et al., 2016).
body_sentences.178:
Another line of work addresses parsing into AMRs (Flanigan et al., 2014; Vanderwende et al., 2015; Pust et al., 2015; Artzi et al., 2015), which, like UCCA, abstract away from syntactic distinctions and represent meaning directly, using OntoNotes predi-
cates (Weischedel et al., 2013).
body_sentences.179: Events in AMR may also be evoked by non-verbal predicates, including possessive constructions.
body_sentences.180: Unlike in UCCA, the alignment between AMR concepts and the text is not explicitly marked.
body_sentences.181: While sharing much of this work’s motivation, not anchoring the representation in the text complicates the parsing task, as it requires the alignment to be automatically (and imprecisely) detected.
body_sentences.182: Indeed, despite considerable technical effort (Flanigan et al., 2014; Pourdamghani et al., 2014; Werling et al., 2015), concept identification is only about 80%–90% accurate.
body_sentences.183: Furthermore, anchoring allows breaking down sentences into semantically meaningful sub-spans, which is useful for many applications (Fernández-González and Martins, 2015; Birch et al., 2016).
body_sentences.184: Several transition-based AMR parsers have been proposed: CAMR assumes syntactically parsed input, processing dependency trees into AMR (Wang et al., 2015a,b, 2016; Goodman et al., 2016).
body_sentences.185: In contrast, the parsers of Damonte et al.
body_sentences.189: (2017) perform concept identification using a simple heuristic selecting the most frequent graph for each token, and Zhou et al.
body_sentences.190: (2016) perform concept identification and parsing jointly.
body_sentences.191: UCCA parsing does not require separately aligning the input tokens to the graph.
body_sentences.192: TUPA creates non-terminal units as part of the parsing process.
body_sentences.193: Furthermore, existing transition-based AMR parsers are not general DAG parsers.
body_sentences.194: They are only able to predict a subset of reentrancies and discontinuities, as they may remove nodes before their parents have been predicted (Damonte et al., 2017).
body_sentences.195: They are thus limited to a sub-class of AMRs in particular, and specifically cannot produce arbitrary DAG parses.
body_sentences.196: TUPA’s transition set, on the other hand, allows general DAG parsing.13  7 Conclusion  We present TUPA, the first parser for UCCA.
body_sentences.197: Evaluated in in-domain and out-of-domain settings, we show that coupled with a NN classifier and BiLSTM feature extractor, it accurately predicts UCCA graphs from text, outperforming a variety of strong baselines by a margin.
body_sentences.198:
Despite the recent diversity of semantic pars-
13See Appendix E for a proof sketch for the completeness of TUPA’s transition set.
body_sentences.199: ing work, the effectiveness of different approaches for structurally and semantically different schemes is not well-understood (Kuhlmann and Oepen, 2016).
body_sentences.200: Our contribution to this literature is a general parser that supports multiple parents, discontinuous units and non-terminal nodes.
body_sentences.201: Future work will evaluate TUPA in a multilingual setting, assessing UCCA’s cross-linguistic applicability.
body_sentences.202: We will also apply the TUPA transition scheme to different target representations, including AMR and SDP, exploring the limits of its generality.
body_sentences.203: In addition, we will explore different conversion procedures (Kong et al., 2015) to compare different representations, suggesting ways for a data-driven design of semantic annotation.
body_sentences.204: A parser for UCCA will enable using the framework for new tasks, in addition to existing applications such as machine translation evaluation (Birch et al., 2016).
body_sentences.205: We believe UCCA’s merits in providing a cross-linguistically applicable, broadcoverage annotation will support ongoing efforts to incorporate deeper semantic structures into various applications, such as sentence simplification (Narayan and Gardent, 2014) and summarization (Liu et al., 2015).
